title: Can you learn a language without speaking it? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes, the entire subcontinent is a living breathing example of people who learn English without speaking it. Most people of subcontinent who think they can speak English are in for a big surprise when they step into an actual English-speaking country. I have seen people from South Asia with masters degrees in English, people who used to teach English not being able to articulate a single sentence in the language when it comes to convey a simple verbal communication about something as simple as giving directions. Written English is a completely different animal from what people of English-speaking countries use in their daily lives. They problem is that many South Asians do not even try to shed the bad lingual habits that they picked up while learning English in school. These habits are forced upon the students because this is how their teachers were taught. The more they think they know English less flexible they are in their conversation-style or improve their language. The ones who think they know how to speak English speak the worst type of the language. Heck, I’ve had similar experience with Arabic too. Back in the day, when learned Arabic was still fresh in my mind, I tried using it in Saudi Arabia. Big mistake. After two such failed attempts, I started to learn the language anew from the locals, and tried forgetting what I had read in books.

It’s not the same question than the one I received by email: How is it possible to understand a language without speaking it? This happens frequently when parents communicate in a language but don’t use it when talking to their offsprings. The children will generally have a good to excellent understanding of this language without being able to speak it. This is encountered very frequently in many countries where immigrants think they must speak to their children in the local language, a language their master very poorly/with a strong accent. The children will generally continue speaking the local language of the country they were born in with all the defects the parents have taught them while being unable to revert to the parental language. Their own children will loose also the understanding, unless they live also with the grand-parents. This is how languages are lost in a family, in two steps. The speech is lost first, the understanding in the next generation.

I think you could learn to read and write in a foreign language, but wouldn't you want at least to listen to it even if you never had the opportunity to speak it? To watch the TV and listen to the radio? To sing songs and say ‘good morning’ to people? To maybe take a little holiday where you could use the language? You will be missing a great deal if you don't learn to speak or understand the spoken language. Most languages sound very different from your language - and if you don't hear it, you won't know how the words are pronounced. Language is about communication, remember that.

response.answer_text: Language disability Learning a language is the combination of listening, reading, writing and speaking. Speaking is very important to learn. If you do not know how to speak a language, how are you going to communicate with people who know that language? For instance, if an arm is missing from the body of a person, that person is disable. If the speaking is missing, that means the person has a language disability. His or her language is not complete. When a student wants to learn a new language, he or she must learn how to write, read, listen and speak that language. If one component is missing, your language is disable.

By memorization people can learn to understand a language if a language it’s similar or related or close enough to another or your native tongue or a language you understand you don’t even need to memorize it because it’s understandable to some degree, people can learn to read many languages based on the criteria above, and understand a few but speak way fewer, not as hard as you may think anyway as long as you pay attention, focus and and effort.

‘Can I learn to speak a language verbally without practicing to speak it?’ That is the question I received via e-mail which does not really make sense to me. I think the answer is ‘No’. Now I see the question is ‘can you learn a language without speaking it’, and the answer is ‘Yes’. Many people learn Latin, Greek, Aramaic, Sanskrit, and other languages in just such a way. It takes many years of dedicated work to get good, however. It also helps if you work on acquiring an active knowledge of the language so that you could speak it, if given the opportunity.

It's pretty typical for academics to learn to read second languages without learning how to speak them. Obvious examples include Latin, ancient Greek, and Sanskrit, where opportunities to use them in conversation are rare. But it's probably even more common for living languages that provide plenty of texts to study. For research, I can adequately read documents in Italian and Spanish but I couldn't really put a sentence together.

I can offer an opinion. I have studied Japanese independently for several years, and still have a few more to go before I’ll be fluent, or near-fluent in reading and writing it. My original motive in taking up Japanese was to read the language--literature, news, magazines, etc.—because I am interested in the mindset of the Japanese people. I’m getting better. I think I could pass JLPT3, or whatever its current name is, and on a good day I think I could pass JLPT2. Several years, plus a few more to go—a long time because I seldom study spoken Japanese. So, with that in mind, in my opinion maybe one’s progress is slower if one studies only written Japanese, but I believe one can become fluent in written Japanese, given enough time and effort.

Yes. I have been able to read complete german books without knowing how to pronounce the words. I learned that later but, as a child, I was able to understand written German with a terrible French biased way of thinking (my mother language).

It depends: If you don’t speak a language how can you learn to pronounce it? In order to learn a language you need to learn how to write, read, listen and speak. Obviously you can learn to write, read and listen but at some point you’re gonna have to speak. If you are learning a language by yourself at home this part sometimes might be difficult but you can practice by yourself listening to videos or audios and repeting it.

I don’t remember speaking much Latin, although I did learn it at school and passed my GCE in it. We really didn’t know how the Ancient Romans spoke, though I guess it sounded like modern Italian. Anyway, we were taught a sort of flat pronunciation, and had to verbally translate various sentences, read Virgil, and learn vocabualry and grammar. However, having a conversation in Latin never really happened.

And don’t forgot that a lot of people learn Latin and Greek and never speak them. It depends on what you are looking for. If your goal is to read Don Quijote in the original, you don’t have to learn to speak Spanish, although it would be nice and could be useful.
People do it with Ancient Greek and Latin all the time. A certain degree of oral fluency is necessary, but neither is actually “spoken”.
You can learn how to read in a foreign language; speaking requires practice either with a buddy or with a teacher.
There is always one language everyone can guess or understand sign or acting language, Uts a start then you repeat the word , copy, mimic, and memorize.
